description:
Adelges cooleyi, commonly known as the Cooley spruce gall adelgid, is a species of aphid-like insect that primarily infests spruce trees. It belongs to the order Hemiptera and the family Adelgidae.

The Cooley spruce gall adelgid has a complex life cycle that involves two host plants: spruce (Picea spp.) and Douglas-fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii). The insects feed on the sap of the host plants, causing the formation of distinctive galls on the branches of spruce trees.

These galls are typically cone-shaped or globular in appearance and can range in size from a few centimeters to several centimeters in diameter. The galls provide shelter and protection for the developing adelgid nymphs, which undergo several molts before emerging as winged adults.

The Cooley spruce gall adelgid is an important forest pest, as the galls can cause disfigurement and growth reduction in affected spruce trees. It is widely distributed in North America, where it can be found throughout the western United States and Canada.

Research on this species has focused on understanding its life cycle, host plant interactions, and the development of effective management strategies to minimize the impact of this insect on commercial and ornamental spruce plantings.
